SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: INTRODUCTION
BLURBS_A:
So you just got your first guitar & can't wait to hit the stage & start earning those millions!? Well, simmer down, there, Sparky, your adoring fans will have to hold out while you get a handle on the basics first. Little Wing wasn't built in a day, & neither will your next masterpiece.

The most important factors in playing music is knowing what chords & notes sound harmonious, & how to call them by name. This lesson aims to illuminate those skills & get you ready to jam out with other musicians. So grab that guitar, tune it up, & stick around a while - you'll be plucking your next hit soon enough!

SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: KEY CHORD FINDER
BLURBS_A:
Composing a good song merely consists of knowing which chords sound good together. The best way to approach this is to pick a Major chord to begin with. The Key Chord Finder below will help you know which other chords will sound good alongside that chord. Select a chord & see the complimentary chords in that Key (keep ignoring those  l,
a, & p for now):

You may notice that when you select certain Keys, a different Key is displayed. This is because certain Keys are irrational. We won't go into details as to why, but just note that: B Sharp is C; C Flat is B; E Sharp is F; F Flat is E - also: G Sharp is A Flat; A Sharp is B Flat; D Sharp is E Flat. Don't worry so much about these rules now, just know that the app isn't broken!
There are many other types of chords, such as: Sustained, Seventh, & add9 - but for now let's just focus on these basic chords as all chords are based off of these primary structures.

SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: KEY CHORD RANDOMIZER
BLURBS_A: Go ahead & pick four chords from the Key Chord Finder above, then play one after another & it will magically sound like a song! If you need some help getting started, use this Key Chord Randomizer to get you going. Select a Key & you will be shown 4 chords from that Key. If you select the same Key twice in a row it will re-randomize. & there's your first hit song!

The Key Chord Randomizer gives you four random chords. These chords could be played in order: 1, 2, 3, 4. Or as another option you could play chords 1 & 2 a few times for a 'verse' & then play chords 3 & 4 a few times for a 'chorus'. This is exactly how hit songs are written. In fact, sometimes hit songs are just chords 1 & 2 back & forth for the entire song! I swear, it's true!

SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: THE KEY CHORD SYSTEM
BLURBS_A:
No, it's not magic (well, maybe a little), it's science! The folks who invented music figured out a simple system for knowing which chords belong in a certain Key. Seven chords round out any Major Key & follow this layout:
1 = Major
2 = Minor
3 = Minor
4 = Major
5 = Major
6 = Minor
7 = Diminished

You start with your chosen chord, & list out six additional chords alphabetically (looping back to A after G). Then, the order of the chord types is: Major, Minor, Minor, Major, Major, Minor, Diminished. Don't worry too much about Diminished chords just yet, their usage is a bit more advanced at this time.

SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: FLATS & SHARPS
BLURBS_A:
It's around this point that we need to discuss three little somethings called Flats ( l), Naturals (
a), & Sharps (p). A Natural means the unmodified note; a Flat is one fret (tone) lower than a certain note; a Sharp is one fret (tone) higher than a certain note. In order to help illustrate this, let's look at another method of writing guitar music: Tablature.

SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: TABLATURE
BLURBS_A:
The horizontal lines are the guitar strings. The line at the bottom represents your fattest string, while the line at the top represents your skinniest string. The numbers represent frets. If you play the notes indicated on the Tablature above, you may recognize it as the first line of Old Macdonald. 
All set? Now you know how to read Tablature!

SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: MAJOR SCALES
BLURBS_A: The last thing we'll cover here to get you started is some simple Major Scales. Behold another method of conveying guitar music: the Scale Chart!

This is actually similar to the Chord Charts we've been using, but is a bit different. The horizontal lines represent the strings where - like Tablature - the fattest string is on the bottom of the diagram. The vertical lines are the fret markers, & the dots are where you place your finger & pluck. These are not chords, but are to be played one note after the other, in succession. Start with the left-most dot on the fattest string & play the three notes on that string, one after another. Then move to the next string & play those three notes, again starting from the left. Travel down the guitar until you finish the three notes on the skinny string, then play the whole thing in reverse until you end up back where you started.

Pay attention to the number above the first fret - it is a Fret Marker which indicates which fret that fret represents. If it's a zero, it means the dot is played open for that string.

Hooray! Now you know the Major Scale! If you use the Key Chord Finder above to display the chords in a particular Key, then any of the notes in the Major Scale of the same Key will sound great over those chords!

There are many other types of scales, including: Pentatonic, Minor, & Hexatonic - but for now we'll just focus on the most popular Major Scale.

SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: MAJOR SCALE FINDER
BLURBS_A: Scales can be played all up & down the neck using slightly different fingerings. Using the Scale Finder below, select a Key & then select a Fingering Number. If you change the Key, but don't change the Scale Fingering, the dots won't change, but the Fret Marker will. There are a few more Major Scale fingerings which exist between the three below - see if you can find them!

SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: DAILY EXERCISE ROUTINE
BLURBS_A: Here's an exercise that can help you pull all of these teachings together. Start with the Key Finder &/or the Key Chord Randomizer & select four chords. Open up any simple 'Voice Recorder' App on your phone, hit 'Record', & strum the chords several times in succession, starting over at the first chord after you play the fourth. Then, choose the same Key in the Scale Finder & practice the Scale while listening to your chord-strumming recording. Do this exercise from the start each day & you'll be sure to notice your improvement over the next couple weeks.

SECTION_CONTENT.TITLE: OUTRODUCTION
BLURBS_A:
This is quite a hefty load of information to digest, but as you continue practicing these basic concepts you'll soon arrive at an understanding of the grand puzzle of music composition. & that's where things get REALLY interesting & complicated! Once you've mastered these concepts you'll be primed & ready for the exciting venture of advanced Music Theory.

Happy Strumming!
